questions.text: Which of the following RNA viruses has an 8 segmented genome with its site of replication being the nucleus?
questions.solution:
Influenza virus has an 8 segmented genome. Its site of replication is the nucleus, unlike other RNA viruses. Influenza virus belongs to the Orthomyxoviridae family. 

Most DNA viruses replicate in the nucleus, except pox. Most RNA viruses replicate in the cytoplasm, except retroviruses and orthomyxoviruses.

Examples of segmented viruses (ARBO): 

  • Arenavirus (2 segments)
  • Rotavirus (11 segments)
  • Bunyavirus (3 segments)
  • Orthomyxovirus (8 segments)

The image below shows the segmented genome seen in the influenza virus (Orthomyxoviridae)

questions.text: A microbiologist working on influenza virus in a lab, observes reversal of hemagglutination. What is this phenomenon known as?
questions.solution:
Elution is the process of reversal of hemagglutination and the release of the virus from the red cell surface.

Influenza virus contains two surface antigens:

  • Hemagglutinin (HA) - causes RBC agglutination; facilitates viral entry into cells
  • Neuraminidase (NA) - an enzyme that destroys the receptor HA uses to bind to RBCs causing elution/reversal of hemagglutination. Hence, it is also called a receptor destroying enzyme (RDE).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding antigenic drift?

choices.text: There is a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure
It doesn’t account for the periodic epidemics of influenza
The new antigens thus formed are totally unrelated to the previous antigens
Antibodies to the predecessor viruses do not neutralise the new variants

questions.solution:
Antigenic drift causes a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure.

It accounts for periodic epidemics. This property forms the basis for the development of annual influenza vaccines. 

Antigenic variation is a property of influenza viruses by which it alters the antigenic structure on its surface and thus avoids a host immune response. It is of two types - Antigenic shift and antigenic drift.

  Antigenic shift Antigenic drift
Antigenic structure Abrupt, drastic change Gradual, sequential change 
Periodicity  10 - 20 years 2 - 3 years   
Epidemiological effect Pandemics and major epidemics  Periodic epidemic and sporadic cases
Genetic cause Large genetic re-assortment Point mutation
Antibodies to predecessor strains Do not neutralize the new variant Neutralizes the new variant to varying degrees
Clinical relevance  Animal-origin viruses infecting humans e.g. Swine flu, COVID-19

Annual influenza vaccine development

Common cold - People can get flu more than once

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is represented by the given form of replication?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the replication of influenza virus.

Stages of replication:

  1. Attachment, penetration, uncoating- the virus is internalized by receptor-mediated endocytosis 
  2. Transcription and translation- Viral transcription occurs in the nucleus. The mRNAs are produced from viral nucleocapsids.
  3. Viral RNA replication- Viral genome replication is accomplished by the same virus-encoded polymerase proteins involved in transcription.
  4. Maturation- The virus matures by budding from the surface of the cell.

questions.text: You receive multiple patients from a poultry farm presenting with fever, dyspnea, cold, and cough. You suspect an outbreak of Avian flu. Which of the following virus strains causes the same?
questions.solution:
H5N1 is a strain of avian influenza.

Transmission occurs only from birds (e.g. poultry). Recombination occurs in pigs. Human-to-human transmission is very rare. 

It causes flu-like symptoms and can cause severe respiratory illness. 

Option A: H1N1 causes swine flu

Option C: H3N2 causes Hong Kong flu

Option D: H2N2 caused a pandemic in 1957

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl with a history of fever, rhinorrhea, sore throat, and myalgia presented with multiple episodes of vomiting and seizures. She was diagnosed with Reye's syndrome. Which of the following is incorrect about the most likely etiological agent?

choices.text: Virus shedding is present before symptoms begins
5-12 years is a high risk group

questions.solution:
The most likely etiological agent in the given case of Reye's syndrome is the influenza virus.  Children <5-years, especially those <2-years of age are at the highest risk of serious complications related to influenza infection. Other high-risk groups for influenza include adults ≥60 years of age, persons with chronic diseases, persons who are immunocompromised.

Option A: The virus is shed in respiratory secretions a day before the onset of illness and for 3-4 days thereafter.

Option C: Birds, especially aquatic birds act as reservoirs of influenza viruses.

Option D: Secondary attack rate is 5-15%.

Note: Reye's syndrome is precipitated by the interaction of a viral infection (such as influenza) with salicylates. Therefore, aspirin is not given to pediatric patients with influenza and influenza-like illness.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with complaints of headache and drowsiness since 2 days. He had a history of fever, ear pain, and difficulty in swallowing for 1 week. On examination, you see the following. Brudzinki's sign is positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with fever, parotitis, headache, drowsiness, and positive Brudzinki's sign is suggestive of meningitis secondary to mumps. 

Mumps is caused by the mumps virus and is characterized by fever, bilateral or unilateral parotid swelling which may be tender. Parotitis can present with ear pain and difficulty in swallowing. It usually resolves in a week.

Meningoencephalitis/aseptic meningitis can occur before, along with, or after parotitis. Most commonly, it manifests 5 days after parotitis. It can present with headache, neck stiffness, and drowsiness.

Complications of mumps:

  • Aseptic meningitis or meningoencephalitis
  • Epididymo-orchitis- Usually unilateral. Seen in post-pubertal males
  • Oophoritis
  • Other complications include pancreatitis and myocarditis

Note: Non-mumps parotitis can be caused by:

  • Epstein-Barr virus - causes infectious mononucleosis
  • Coxsackievirus - causes herpangina
  • Parainfluenza virus - causes croup

questions.text: A  9-month-old child is brought to the OPD for MMR vaccine. Which strain of mumps virus is used in the same?
questions.solution:
The strain of mumps virus used in the MMR vaccine (Measles, Mumps, Rubella) is the Jeryl-Lynn strain. 

The virus is attenuated by serial passage in embryonated eggs and grown in chick embryo fibroblast culture. 

Note: The schedule of MMR vaccine as per the National Immunisation Schedule is from 9 completed months to 12 months. (can be given till 5 years of age).

questions.text: A mother brings her 5-month-old baby to the casualty with complaints of fast breathing and poor feeding. She also gives a history of fever, cold, and cough for 3 days. On examination, nasal flaring and expiratory wheeze are present. Which of the following statements is false about the viral etiology of the same?

choices.text: The cytopathic effect is syncytium formation
Ribavirin is the drug of choice
It is the most important cause of bronchiolitis

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bronchiolitis caused by the respiratory syncytial virus (RSV). Palivizumab is given for RSV prophylaxis in high-risk infants such as premature babies, immunocompromised infants, etc. 

Option A - The characteristic cytopathic effect is syncytium formation (multinucleated giant cell). 

Option B - Inhaled ribavirin is the drug of choice. 

Option D - RSV causes upper and lower respiratory tract infections in infants, and is the most common cause of bronchiolitis from ages 6 weeks to 6 months. It can cause pneumonia and tracheobronchitis and is common during winters and monsoon.

questions.text: An unimmunized man presents with fever, malaise, and an erythematous rash starting from behind the ears and progressing to the face and trunk. Given below is an image of lymphoid tissue taken from this patient. What pathological finding do you see here?
questions.solution:
Warthin-Finkeldey cells are seen here. These are multinucleate giant cells, which are found in the lymphoid tissues of patients with measles.

The cytopathic effect of measles consists of multinucleate syncytium formation with numerous acidophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions, as shown in the image below.

Option B: Warthin-Starry stain is used to detect spirochetes and to stain H. pylori and B. henselae

Option C: Langhans giant cells are seen in tuberculosis 

Option D: Aschoff giant cells are seen in rheumatic fever

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy with no prior immunization history presents with fever, cough, and coryza. On examination of the buccal mucosa, you see the following. Which stage of the disease is this finding seen in?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Koplik’s spots present in measles. They are seen during the prodromal phase of the illness.  

Koplik's spots are small bluish-white ulcerations on the buccal mucosa opposite to the first and second lower molars and are pathognomonic of measles. They contain giant cells, cytoplasmic and intranuclear inclusions, and virion components. They can involve the entire buccal mucosa and fade as the maculopapular rash develops.

Stages of measles:

The natural history of measles has 3 stages as follows:

  1. Prodromal stage - It begins 10 days after infection and lasts until day 14. It consists of cough, coryza, redness of eyes, lacrimation, photophobia, vomiting, and diarrhea. Koplik's spots appear in this stage. 
  2. Eruptive stage - A dusky, red maculopapular rash appears. It starts behind the ears spreads downwards to the trunk and lower extremities. Antibodies appear in this stage and are detectable by IgM ELISA. The symptoms such as fever and rash usually resolve spontaneously or go on to develop complications.
  3. Post-measles stage - Weakness and weight loss may persist. The infection may become chronic and cause secondary infections such as cancrum oris, candidiasis etc.

questions.text: Which of the following disease has the highest mortality once clinically manifested?
questions.solution:
Rabies is a vaccine-preventable, zoonotic, viral disease. Once clinical symptoms appear, rabies is virtually 100% fatal.

Spread of rabies:

  • Centripetal spread -
    • The virus enters the peripheral neurons, it moves via retrograde fast axonal transport towards the spinal cord or brainstem a.k.a the central nervous system (CNS) at a speed of up to 250 mm/day.
    • Once within CNS, it spreads quickly to other regions in the CNS through fast axonal transport. It infects neurons primarily, but may rarely infect astrocytes.
  • Centrifugal spread - After CNS infection is established, it spreads along the sensory and autonomic nerves to: 
    • Salivary glands 
    • Adrenal glands
    • Skin 

Rabies virus replicates in acinar cells of the salivary glands and is secreted in the saliva of rabid animals that serve as vectors.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pet-groomer was brought to the casualty with a history of breathlessness, excessive agitation, and restlessness. His bystanders give a history of progressive behavioral change and he had a fever, sore throat, and generalized weakness 1 month back. On examination, pulse was 100 bpm, SpO2 was 98% on room air.  Which of the following samples will not be preferred to detect the etiological agent?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is highly suggestive of rabies. Corneal impression smears are not performed, as they are of low diagnostic yield.

Laboratory diagnosis of rabies is performed by the following methods:

  • Antigen detection - Direct immunofluorescence (IF) from specimens of :
    • Skin biopsy from the nape of the neck including hair follicles. Rabies antigen is present in cutaneous nerves at the base of hair follicles. It is the most sensitive and specific test.
    • Corneal smears were previously used. They are not used anymore as they are of low diagnostic yield.
  • Viral isolation- Intracerebral inoculation in mice can be attempted from the brain, CSF, and saliva.
  • Antibody demonstration from serum and CSF.
  • Viral RNA detection by RT-PCR .
  • Postmortem examination of brain tissue samples- demonstration of Negri bodies.

questions.text: An officer of the Indian Forest Services is bitten by a rabid fox while on duty. Which of the following statements is true about the etiological agent?

choices.text: The incubation period is 4 to 5 days

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of infection with the street form of rabies virus. Street rabies causes disease.

All mammals are susceptible to rabies. Cattle, cats and foxes are highly susceptible, whereas dogs and humans have intermediate susceptibility. 

Differences between street rabies and fixed rabies:

Street rabies Fixed rabies (produced by repeated passages)
Causes disease Doesn't cause disease
Produces Negri body Doesn't produce Negri body
Affects salivary glands Doesn't affect salivary glands
Incubation period- 3 months Incubation period- 4-5 days

questions.text: A 23-year-old man was brought to you with a history of fever, behavioral changes, and seizures. He is foaming at the mouth and is unable to ingest liquids. The patient was admitted to the ICU, however he died soon after. Post mortem brain samples showed the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing Negri bodies and the case scenario of fever, neurological symptoms like seizures and altered sensorium, hydrophobia (due to painful muscle contractions during swallowing liquids), and hypersalivation are suggestive of encephalitic rabies.

Negri bodies are eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons that are composed of rabies virus proteins and viral RNA. These are commonly observed in Purkinje cells of the cerebellum and in pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus. Their presence is a characteristic pathologic finding in rabies.

questions.text: Babes nodules are seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Babes nodules are seen in rabies. Mononuclear inflammatory infiltration in the leptomeninges, including microglial nodules are called Babes nodules.

The most characteristic pathologic finding in rabies is the Negri body. These are eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions in brain neurons that are composed of rabies virus proteins and viral RNA. The image given below shows Negri bodies.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding rabies vaccination?

choices.text: Bitten dog should be observed for a minimum of 10 days.
Four-dose regimen is given as 0.1ml intramuscularly on days 0, 3, 7 and 28.
Pre-exposure prophylaxis regimen consists of 3 doses.
The dose of human anti rabies immunoglobulin is 20 IU/kg.

questions.solution:
According to the Updated Thai Red Cross Regimen (2-2-2-0-2) for post exposure prophylaxis, reconstituted rabies vaccine is given as follows:

  • 0.1 ml intradermally
  • Sites - two sites at the same visit. It is given in both the deltoids
  • Schedule - Days 0, 3, 7, and 28

Healthy dogs, cats, or ferrets may be confined and observed for 10 days.

The dosage of equine rabies immunoglobulin (eRIG) is 40 IU/kg while that of human anti-rabies immunoglobulin (hRIG) is 20 IU/kg body weight.

PrEP regimens for individuals of all ages are as follows:

  • Three intramuscular or intradermal vaccine doses on days 0, 7, and 21 or 28.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment
